snippet.textDisplay: A piece of critical information is mispresented in the video. Ciri was promised to Geralt through Law of Suprise. The law of surprise was invoked when Geralt saved Duny (aka Emyhr) in the presentation ceremony for Pavetta's wedding (Guess what, every other King tried to kill the Hedgehog when he wanted to marry Pavetta through his Law of Surprise). Law of Surprise can't be invoked just because you want to, you have to save someone's life.
snippet.textOriginal: A piece of critical information is mispresented in the video. Ciri was promised to Geralt through Law of Suprise. The law of surprise was invoked when Geralt saved Duny (aka Emyhr) in the presentation ceremony for Pavetta's wedding (Guess what, every other King tried to kill the Hedgehog when he wanted to marry Pavetta through his Law of Surprise). Law of Surprise can't be invoked just because you want to, you have to save someone's life.

snippet.textDisplay: This still doesn't add up to connect with the tv series...unless everyone has been brainwashed multiple times. Lot of inconsistent jumping back and forth/flashbacks in both the series and the games that try to explain something so it makes sense only at the moment you are actively paying attention, but causes you to realize that if you add all those stories together it's not at all linear. Multiverses suck at keeping things in a meaningful order...just go with it and be happy... or emotionally detached
snippet.textOriginal: This still doesn't add up to connect with the tv series...unless everyone has been brainwashed multiple times. Lot of inconsistent jumping back and forth/flashbacks in both the series and the games that try to explain something so it makes sense only at the moment you are actively paying attention, but causes you to realize that if you add all those stories together it's not at all linear. Multiverses suck at keeping things in a meaningful order...just go with it and be happy... or emotionally detached

snippet.textDisplay: I didn't kill Letho for several reasons. 1, he's just a tool and he saved Yen. 2, He spared Geralt. Actually, he and Geralt are actually friends (Geralt just lost that part of memory until the end). Geralt even killed  Auckes and Serrit (they are also Geralt friends). Geralt fought alongside them previously so they must be somewhat of close friends. I hate how the game did not indicate Geralt's grief after realizing he unknowingly killed 2 friends of his once he got the memory back. That does not like Geralt. Letho even got thrown in jail for protecting Yen and he got no choice but to be an assassin or Emhyr will kill Yen. Letho was killing kings to protect Yen. Emhyr probably gave Letho time limit to kill the kings. If Letho didn't kill the kings within a certain time, Yen will be killed and Letho and his friends will be hunted down. 3, most of the kings actually deserved to be killed. They are corrupted and evil. I believe let Letho go is the right thing to do.
snippet.textOriginal: I didn't kill Letho for several reasons. 1, he's just a tool and he saved Yen. 2, He spared Geralt. Actually, he and Geralt are actually friends (Geralt just lost that part of memory until the end). Geralt even killed  Auckes and Serrit (they are also Geralt friends). Geralt fought alongside them previously so they must be somewhat of close friends. I hate how the game did not indicate Geralt's grief after realizing he unknowingly killed 2 friends of his once he got the memory back. That does not like Geralt. Letho even got thrown in jail for protecting Yen and he got no choice but to be an assassin or Emhyr will kill Yen. Letho was killing kings to protect Yen. Emhyr probably gave Letho time limit to kill the kings. If Letho didn't kill the kings within a certain time, Yen will be killed and Letho and his friends will be hunted down. 3, most of the kings actually deserved to be killed. They are corrupted and evil. I believe let Letho go is the right thing to do.

snippet.textDisplay: Not to be nitpicky, but Sapkowski's books predate A song of Ice and Fire; to say that the world of the Witcher is like the one of Game of Thrones is not a very sound comparison, maybe it should be the other way around (if at all).
snippet.textOriginal: Not to be nitpicky, but Sapkowski's books predate A song of Ice and Fire; to say that the world of the Witcher is like the one of Game of Thrones is not a very sound comparison, maybe it should be the other way around (if at all).

snippet.textDisplay: Someone recommended that I play Witcher 3 a long time ago, had it sitting in my Steam library. I have to say, best game ever!  Great story. First play through I got the sad ending but on the second play through (via New Game +) I changed me decisions & got the Witcher ending.  I'm interested to see what they do next, though it won't be following Geralt or Ciri from what I've read.
snippet.textOriginal: Someone recommended that I play Witcher 3 a long time ago, had it sitting in my Steam library. I have to say, best game ever!  Great story. First play through I got the sad ending but on the second play through (via New Game +) I changed me decisions & got the Witcher ending.  I'm interested to see what they do next, though it won't be following Geralt or Ciri from what I've read.

snippet.textDisplay: the one who asked Geralt to leave Blaviken and never returned were not the townfolks, but the Alderman of Blaviken himself, Caldemeyn, he's one of Geralt's friends, he even came to Geralt and Yennefer's wedding, the reason why Caldemeyn asked him to leave and never return was because the townfolk will never forget what he did and only see him as a ruthless monster, so to avoid conflict he asked him to leave and never returned,  basically Caldemeyn doesn't want to see his friend who did nothing wrong, treated as a monster and he wasn't being warned, but he was being asked kindly by his friend,
snippet.textOriginal: the one who asked Geralt to leave Blaviken and never returned were not the townfolks, but the Alderman of Blaviken himself, Caldemeyn, he's one of Geralt's friends, he even came to Geralt and Yennefer's wedding, the reason why Caldemeyn asked him to leave and never return was because the townfolk will never forget what he did and only see him as a ruthless monster, so to avoid conflict he asked him to leave and never returned,  basically Caldemeyn doesn't want to see his friend who did nothing wrong, treated as a monster and he wasn't being warned, but he was being asked kindly by his friend,

snippet.textDisplay: You totally left out that Jaque (the final boss from the first game, if you don't battle de Wild Hunt) is a boy that Geralt had to protect and interacted with for a while. Trully tragic and "plot twistty".

snippet.textDisplay:
Spoilers***

Actually taking Ciri to Emyr doesn't worsen their relationship depending on the choices you make. I love that if you beat hearts of stone before the Isle of mists you can ask Gaunter about finding her and he'll essentially tell you all the right decisions to beat the game with a good ending. Be warned though, he will specifically say that no matter what happens, DON'T SELL HER OUT! That scene with her and Emyr is the reference. If you take the money for finding her you'll lock in the worst ending. If you don't you'll have a moment where she looks at you endearingly and grabs your hand. It's the best moment a father could ask for.

Also, it will lead you towards the empress ending, but if you haven't beat Djikstra's spy questline, you have an opportunity to get the Witcher ending for Ciri, but it's a hard decision. You have to agree to leave when Djikstra betrays both Roche and Thaler, leaving them to die, but it ensures Redania's victory against Nilfgard and forfeits the bitter sweet empress ending for Ciri's Witcher ending.
snippet.textOriginal:
Spoilers***

Actually taking Ciri to Emyr doesn't worsen their relationship depending on the choices you make. I love that if you beat hearts of stone before the Isle of mists you can ask Gaunter about finding her and he'll essentially tell you all the right decisions to beat the game with a good ending. Be warned though, he will specifically say that no matter what happens, DON'T SELL HER OUT! That scene with her and Emyr is the reference. If you take the money for finding her you'll lock in the worst ending. If you don't you'll have a moment where she looks at you endearingly and grabs your hand. It's the best moment a father could ask for.

Also, it will lead you towards the empress ending, but if you haven't beat Djikstra's spy questline, you have an opportunity to get the Witcher ending for Ciri, but it's a hard decision. You have to agree to leave when Djikstra betrays both Roche and Thaler, leaving them to die, but it ensures Redania's victory against Nilfgard and forfeits the bitter sweet empress ending for Ciri's Witcher ending.

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel the bad ending may just be the best one in a very twisted way. It's certainly the most dramatic and impactful one. And the symbolism of the monsters crawling in while geralt holds the medallion is just beautiful.

Or maybe I'm just in denial because I got that ending.

snippet.textDisplay: My first play through of the witcher wild hunt I got the ending where geralt and ciri go about witchering together and I was in salt happy after playing through it a few more times I can thoroughly say my first play through was the best killing radived, romancing yennefer, becoming a father daughter witcher duo with ciri and finally living happily ever after in tousiant was the best ending for the series. 10/10 would recommend if you have never played the games or read the books.

snippet.textDisplay:
in case anyone got introduced to the Witcher through the new Netflix series.... see that chick in the middle of the thumbnail? That's Yen, Yennefer...so why is she some Indian girl in the show??? well, you can thank inclusive anti-white SJWs for that one. They were about to make Ciri(girl on the right) black as well, and I'm still fearful for the freckled redhead Triss. Some other minor characters also got black-washed.

But of course, if I rant and talk about it I MUST be some white supremacist nazi racist bigot. If we did the same to "minorities"(more like majorities) they'd call their own rants "racial/cultural preservation". Ah, double standards, gotta love em.
